bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed and Blossom Reed, November 30, 1900

div1.p: Reed expresses empathy for his wife's gout. He writes that the experimental camp is almost completed and will soon be ready for work.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed and Blossom Reed, November 30, 1900
div1.p:
Your
dear letter of the 22nd Came
on Wednesday, and yesterday
being Thanksgiving & your
old Mr Mantee being very
much occupied with nu-
merous matters, he hasn't
had time to write until
this morning- I declare
lovie, dear; I do sympathize
so with you over your
long confinement to the
house, when I know how
very irksome it must be

Deliver me from an at-
tack of the gout! I have
had acute rheumatism
twice and I know how very
annoying that was- Bless
your precious heart! to be
sick and confined to your
room, and no Mr Mantee to
pet and care for you! It
is perfectly dreadful!
But it might be worse.
You have a good bed to
lie on and a sweet little
daughter to nurse you
and kind friends and a
good doctor- If you had
none of these, and the
gout in both big toes,
how much worse it
would be! Now do you
see how well off you
are? I know that you
are uncomplaining and
as patient as you can
be, but it is tiresome to
be shut in, especially when
the weather is so warm
and pleasant- Never mind,
the gout will not last
much longer and then you
will able to take the fresh
air once more- Just
to think that this is the
last day of November!
To you the month has seemed
long, I know, but to me
it has fairly flown away!
I never saw this pass
so rapidly- The day is gone
before I can realize it.
The finishing touches are
now being put to our second
house in the camp and I
am so anxious to see it
completed and everything
in good shape for our
work-

Friday night- Dr Stark has just
been in and chatted with me
for an hour- He is fond
of dropping in and discussing
the mosquito theory with
me and talking over profes-
sional things general- Mrs.
Stark is very sociable and
often invites me over, to
tea or dinner- Every morn-
ing, one of her dear little
boys -- Alec -- the older one --
comes over to see me; and
if on questioning him, he
says that he has been
“a good boy”, I then give
him a good hug, at
which he seems to be
very much amused and happy.
Tell me, dearest, what did
my precious wifie have
for her thanksgiving dinner?
I declare that I should
have enjoyed my dinner
more, had I not thought
of my poor miss Gouty
who was being deprived
of hers! I do hope that
Dr Nash gave my sweet
Farmer-lady permission
to digest a little piece of
the white meat of the Tur-
key- If he didn't, I shall
be real mad with him
for being a cruel, cruel
doctor! We really had
in our mess a very ex-
cellent dinner, winding
up with Plum pudding
and Mince-pie! Think
of Mince-pie in Cuba
when the weather is
almost like Summer!
I took the P.P., but left
the others to consume
the Mince! This afternoon,
Col. Burton, the Inspector
General of the Department,
came to call on me-
you will remember him
as a Captain at Fort
Sydney- He has changed
very little during these
16 years, since I last
saw him- His wife and
daughters remain in
the U.S.- This morning,
Dr Truby left us for Cien-
fuegos, Cuba, Darboy's
station- He belongs to the
medical corps, and is
such a splendid young
fellow & good companion,
that we all hated to
see him go- He will be
such an improvement on
the medical officers now
on duty at Cienfuegos
Saturday morning -- Dec. 1st- what
has become with Papa's daugh-
ter that she doesn't write to
him any more? Is the precious
child too busy with her lessons
and that pretty dress? or will
Papa find a letter in to-day's
mail from her? That would
be a very great joy to her
darling father- The morning
is just a bit chilly and as
father sits & writes, clothed
only in his beautiful pajam-
as, he doesn't find himself any
too warm- He so much hopes
that to-day's letter will tell of his
sweet, sweet wifie's great im-
provement- That would make
him very happy. Boo! Boo!
kisses and love and love & kisses
for his precious girls-
